title: 114_s460
content: The "Drinking Water Protection Act" is cited as the short title. The Safe Drinking Water Act is amended to include a section on Algal Toxin Risk Assessment and Management. The Administrator must develop a strategic plan for assessing and managing risks associated with algal toxins in drinking water from public water systems, including evaluating health risks and listing harmful algal toxins. The Administrator must assess algal toxins in drinking water from public systems for adverse health effects and factors causing toxin production. The Administrator must assess algal toxins in drinking water from public systems for adverse health effects and factors causing toxin production. This includes determining whether to publish health advisories, establish guidance on analytical methods, and recommend treatment options for algal toxins in drinking water. The Administrator is required to develop a strategic plan to address algal toxins in drinking water, including procedures, equipment, and source water protection practices. They must also enter into cooperative agreements and provide technical assistance to affected States and public water systems. Additionally, the Administrator will update and submit the strategic plan to Congress as needed. In carrying out these tasks, gaps in the Agency's understanding of algal toxins must be identified. The Administrator is tasked with identifying gaps in understanding algal toxins, including human health effects and testing methods. They are also required to consult with federal agencies, states, and public water system operators. The Administrator is responsible for gathering information on cyanobacteria and algal toxins from various sources, including federal agencies, states, and public water system operators. A report to Congress by the Comptroller General of the United States is required within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report to Congress detailing funds spent on examining toxin-producing cyanobacteria and algae from 2010 to 2014. The report will also include recommendations to reduce duplication and improve interagency coordination of such expenditures.
